replies.bodyText: Just a generic exception, it is because of upstream, there is no Specific exception defined. It is thrown when the controller is not accepting new connections or when a secure connection cannot be established
replies.author: ecdye

replies.bodyText: If I see correctly the upstream methods are declared with throws OmniInvalidResponseException, OmniUnknownMessageTypeException, BridgeOfflineException. You could catch these in a multi-catch.
replies.author: fwolter

replies.bodyText: I see, the constructor of  Connection in the library is delcared with throws Exception, IOException, UnknownHostException. This is a bit suboptimal, but not the scope of this review. You can leave it as is.

replies.bodyText: From my understanding it is because the OmniPro does not allow requesting the current state of these commands and therefore it cannot be requested.
replies.author: ecdye

replies.bodyText: @J-N-K I think I understand what you mean, however it is hard for me to tell if it is working. Does this look right?

timeline.bodyText: Why don't you use QuantityType here?
timeline.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText: Because it already used DecimalType in the previous version of this binding and I did not think to change it, unless you think it is important, I would prefer to leave it as is.
replies.author: ecdye

replies.bodyText: using a quantity type is simple, new QuantityType<>(temp, temperatureUnit); where temp is your float value and temperatureUnit is either org.openhab.core.library.unit.ImperialUnits.FAHRENHEIT or org.openhab.core.library.unit.SIUnits.CELSIUS depending on what the omni is reporting the value in
replies.author: digitaldan

+    SENSOR_AUX_HIGHF(5007),
+    SENSOR_AUDIOZONE_POWER(6001),
+    SENSOR_AUDIOZONE_SOURCE(6002),
+    SENSOR_AUDIOZONE_VOLUME(6003),
+    SENSOR_AUDIOZONE_MUTE(6004),
+    SENSOR_AUDIOZONE_TEXT(6005),
+    SENSOR_AUDIOZONE_TEXT_FIELD1(6006),
+    SENSOR_AUDIOZONE_TEXT_FIELD2(6007),
+    SENSOR_AUDIOZONE_TEXT_FIELD3(6008),
+    SENSOR_AUDIOSOURCE_TEXT(7001),
+    SENSOR_AUDIOSOURCE_TEXT_FIELD1(7002),
+    SENSOR_AUDIOSOURCE_TEXT_FIELD2(7003),
+    SENSOR_AUDIOSOURCE_TEXT_FIELD3(7004);
+
+    private int number;
+
+    OmniLinkCmd(int number) {
+        this.number = number;
+    }
+
+    public int getNumber() {
+        return number;
+    }
+
+    public static @Nullable OmniLinkCmd getCommand(String name) {
+        for (OmniLinkCmd command : OmniLinkCmd.values()) {

replies.bodyText: I did not write this code, I simply left it how it was as it was still working just fine. I try to operate on the principle of don't fix what isn't broken.
replies.author: ecdye

timeline.bodyText: Is this a good idea? What if the connection is not present? Wouldn't it make more sense to call updateChannels immediately after a successful connection?
timeline.author: J-N-K

replies.bodyText: Yes I thought about that and have changed it in a uncommited update that I am working on.
